utterances: Donna Brazile, that's an interesting point.
History will be the judge.
The president says he won't even be there now to make the decision about pulling troops out.
He thinks that decision will be left to future presidents and future leaders of Iraq.
What do you think?
We are three years into the conflict.
We have a low-grade civil war going on right now.
The president has consistently ignored advice about sending in more troops, gaining more international support.

It's time that the White House put aside all of its rationales for being in Iraq and to sit down with people who can help us figure out a plan to not only bring the three factions together, but also begin to pull our troops out in 2006.
Rev.
Joseph Watkins is a member of the Government Relations Group at Buchanan Ingersoll.
He was a member of the first President Bush's White House staff.
And Donna Brazile was campaign manager for Democratic presidential nominee Al Gore in 2000.
She now runs her own political consulting firm here in Washington.
Thank you both for joining us.
Thank you, Juan.
Thanks, Juan.
Join us every Thursday for Juan Williams and his Washington Insiders, right here on Political Corner.
(Soundbite of music)
Many residents say Hazleton is still a divided city.
While some Spanish speakers build new lives, longtime residents are conflicted about the city's cultural change.
Elizabeth Fiedler of member station WHYY visited Hazleton and she brings us this story.
It's not hard to find a Latino business in Hazleton these days.
We have insurance agents, we have a lawyer, we have a cafeteria, we have a migrant education program.
That's Amilcar Arroyo, the publisher of a local Spanish-language newspaper.
He says Latinos are now firmly establishing themselves as a part of Hazleton.
Children that came with their parents 10 years, seven years ago, at the age of 11, 12, right now they are in the college.
Some of those, they already graduate from college.
They are fully English speaking, they don't speak with accents like me.
This isn't the first time Hazleton has seen a wave of change, says Mayor Joe Yannuzzi, who was born and raised here.
After the war, mines went down, silk mill picked up and left, had this union dispute, and the town crashed.
Yannuzzi says in time there were vacant storefronts, and kids who graduated from high school moved away.
Now, Yannuzzi says, the immigrants have added children to the city's aging population and filled empty storefronts with businesses.
And now it's like maybe 90, 85 percent filled.
We're happy with that.
Now, you just have a problem with the illegals.
Hazleton resident Chris DiRienzo agrees.
I'm all for coming to America and experiencing the American dream but doing it the right way, through the proper channels, is the right thing to do, and a lot of that is not being done here.
DiRienzo says, in his opinion, the city's change has not been for the better.
Longtime Hazleton-area residents are responding to their new neighbors in different ways.
They remind me of my grandparents.
My grandparents came here from Italy - never spoke English.
My mother went into the schools only speaking Italian.
Elaine Maddon Curry helped found a group called Concerned Parents of the Hazleton Area.
We roughly have about 80 to 100 adults who volunteers from the community teach English different times of the day, different times of the week.
We have 43 new American citizens as a result of our classes, and we also do children's programs.
But the city does face some serious problems, says Chief of Police Frank DeAndrea.
One is drugs, you know, one is gangs.
But there are as many white and black members of this entire Hazleton area involved in gangs, as there are Latinos.
DeAndrea, who was born and raised here, says the language gap between new and old residents makes the job of policing even harder.
I need to do something as the chief of police to get them to be able to communicate with half of the community that we serve.
It's only fair to those victims and it's only fair for us to be able to do a thorough investigation.
I need to bridge those gaps quickly.
Demographer Kevin O'Neil says immigrants are coming to Hazleton not just for jobs but also cheap housing, friendly communities, and good schools.
KEVIN O'NEIL: Just dealing with illegality won't change demographics.

It also matters whether communities have the resources to deal with things like rising school enrollments and to be able to provide English language training and to be able to sort of integrate people and bring them into their community.
O'Neil says on a national level, offering undocumented people a path to citizenship could help - by taking illegality out of the equation and by cooling down the political fires.
But, he says, that will not solve all the challenges facing places like Hazleton.
For NPR News, I'm Elizabeth Fiedler.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
And you're listening to NPR News.
A couple of weeks ago, we noticed a small item in the newspaper.
Eighty-three-year-old Jean Clinton Roeschlaub was found murdered in her apartment.
That story caught our eye because Jean was an owner of Clifton's Cafeteria, one of the last Depression era restaurants left in Los Angeles still family run.
No one has been arrested in Jean's murder.
Her family has no idea why anyone would have wanted to kill her.
Clifton's carries on as it has for some 70 years.
Wedged in between discount jewelry stores, it's mainly a lunch spot for shoppers, workers, and everyone else downtown.
To find out why it hasn't been torn down or turned into a Panini Espresso joint, I met Charles Phoenix outside Clifton's.
Charles is an L.A.
historian.
He gives tours of landmarks most people have forgotten.
Clifton's Cafeteria is authentic Los Angeles.
It is at the corner of Seventh and Broadway.
Clifton's has been here since 1935 and it's still going strong today.
Why do people keep coming back here?
I think what they really are coming back for is the unbelievable display of food because it is the grandest cafeteria.
It is not only the grandest cafeteria, it is the largest restaurant in all of Los Angeles.
Six hundred people can be seated at once.
No other restaurant even comes close.
Let's go see this food.
Okay come on.
We're going to see some Jell-O.
(Soundbite of crowd chatter, footfalls, ringing sound)
Okay, before we get to the Jell-O we have to pause to describe the inside of Clifton's.
Charles and I have entered a redwood forest.
The first thing you see is an animatronic raccoon bobbing up and down behind a fake log.
There are murals of redwoods on the walls, a waterfall, and a stream.
Some of the tables are made from giant slabs of trees.
Okay, now back to the Jell-O.
And the third piece is the gradual stabilization of housing.
It's happening slowly, but it's happening.
And, at some point, that means more jobs for carpenters, electricians and lots of other people.
Kotok is the chief investment officer for his firm.
It manages billions of dollars, so he has to put his money where his mouth is on this stuff and he says he is placing his chips on a slow, but continued recovery for the economy and employment.
Chris Arnold, NPR News, Boston.
It's WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Guy Raz.
As President Obama said this week, a China that protects the rights of all its citizens will be a stronger and more prosperous nation and, of course, a stronger partner on behalf of our common goals.
Secretary of State Hillary Clinton speaking from Beijing this week where she was visiting for the U.S.-China strategic dialogue talks.
These are two days of annual meetings held between Washington and Beijing.
And this year, of course, those talks were overshadowed by the events surrounding the dissident Chen Guangcheng.
But James Fallows of The Atlantic who writes often about China was watching those talks closely.
And, Jim, first of all, explain the backstory to these annual talks.
Yes.
This is a legacy of the George W.

Bush administration where under mainly the impetus of then Secretary of the Treasury Hank Paulson, they decided it would be good to have a regular annual occasion for getting together at the highest levels between the Chinese and the American government.
So it was called then the strategic economic dialogue talks.
Now, with the different emphasis of the Obama administration, it's the strategic and economic dialogues.
And it's mainly a way to have a routine guaranteed forum to resolve a lot of the always difficult issues between the two countries.
And, of course, not just Hillary Clinton was there, but Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner.
And does the U.S.
do this with any other country in the world?
Not in this forum because there's no other relationship just like the one between the U.S.
and China.

In dealings with NATO, which is a very friendly relationship, and dealings with the Soviet Union in the old days as an overall very hostile relationship, this is a unique interaction in that it's both cooperative in many ways and hostile and confrontational in some others.
And so I think that's the special role of these discussions.
Obviously, the case of Chen Guangcheng dominated the news coverage of what happened there, but there were things that did actually happen.
What was the U.S.
after in those talks?
